Comment: Each state sets its own refining standards.  California has opted to create a standard that no one else chooses to follow.  Accordingly, the supply of that fuel is limited, as few producers bother with it.  Meanwhile, the money in the oil industry is in the upstream (exploration and controlling the reserves), not in the downstream.  Refining is a low margin business with high barriers to entry, so it doesn't attract much interest.  Accordingly, the free market has little reason to devote resources to addressing the state's (self-inflicted) problem.  The state has two basic options: Either adopt more common standards or else treat refining as a public utility and get into the refining business.  The problem should be easy to understand.  The solutions are debatable.
